wizard album
kg this is a new full-length lp from

sorcerers king gizzard and the lizard
wizard said to be their 16th

in 2020 as well i believe
though they have been dropping demos and
and live tracks as well plus it's also a
pandemic
so who can really blame them for slowing

especially after having dropped two
albums last year and let's not forget
that amazing
five record run back in 2017
so yes king gizzard is still one of the
most exciting and creative
bands out there today even during these
depressing times
and i guess this new project is being
subtly billed as the
second volume in their ongoing micro
tonal series
projects where the band is feeling out
the notes between the notes in your
typical chromatic scale
they did it once before kicking off that
amazing 2017 album run with flying micro
tonal banana which still remains one of
my favorite gizzard albums to this day
but after numerous listens it's pretty
clear the sequel isn't quite as great as
the original
however it still has its moments and
distinct qualities
for one i do appreciate the stylistic
variety the band
tries to bring on this record you can
tell here and there they are trying to
push
this micro tonal thing outside of the
straight psych context that it was in
on the last record and that's done with
more electronics more
acoustic cuts the country-tinged honey
as well as the sabbath worship happening
on the closer too
which is packed with all of these tony
naomi-esque guitar riffs
there are some pretty smooth
instrumental passages segwaying all of
these songs together too
so the album does come off like a
somewhat holistic experience
even if you're switching gears pretty
radically from track to track
the production is a little rough around
the edges which in the case of king
gizzard isn't necessarily a bad thing
they've been known to
do a somewhat low-fi joint or two and
certainly turn that roughness into a
quality a characteristic that adds to

but the fact still remains for me anyway
that this is not a very strong track
list from the band
and while another micro tonal record

the devil of this record really is in
the details of how each of these tracks

in the band's greater discography
kglw isn't just a short intro to the

these
mysterious plucky acoustic passages and
desolate desert woodwinds
there's a real middle eastern vibe to it
that carries over into the next track
automation and while there is an exotic

the vocals the definitely brittle mix

feeling pretty

it's a jam things move in an even more

on straws in the wind another one of
this record's sharp acoustic cuts
the recording is dirty and loaded with

but somehow the sonic aesthetics of this
track really
play into the songs themes of evil
end times and life being so fleeting as
humanity seems to be on an
endless mission to destroy itself the
following
some of us is a groovy psych jam packed
with these
relentlessly sour lead melodies that
just do not
smooth out i could tell the band is

which is admirable but they just give
you
nothing to chase this melody to take the
edge off of
how bitter it comes off combine that
with the mind

the melody is stickier the rhythms are
peppier the layering just feels richer
plus there are some grand instrumental

that

intrasport is likely going to generate

because of its very odd combination of

the band really laying a lot of

closer

so yeah i think this is an okay record
